decision_conditions: The Oak tree is situated within the front garden on the boundary line with 34a and as a result has a high amenity value. The Horse Chestnut is situated within the rear garden of 32 and can be seen from the public right of way to the side of the property. As a result it has a moderate to high amenity value. Both trees significantly contribute to the arboricultural character of Ruislip Conservation area.

Both trees have been subject to past management however no reasons have been provided for the work to the Horse Chestnut and as a result there is no justification as to why 3m more than previously needs to be removed. The Oak tree does have a slightly lopsided crown (when viewed looking straight at the properties) but there is no justification as to why this has now become something to rectify.
Having regard to the reasons given for the proposed work, the work is unjustified and will have a detrimental impact on the visual amenity and arboreal character of the area.
The removal of deadwood, dangerous / hanging branches and ivy:  This does not require the formal consent of the Council.
description: To carry out tree surgery, including a crown reduction to previous points with an additional 2m reduction on the est side, to one oak, T3 on TPO 507, and to crown reduce by 3m more than previous, to one Horse Chestnut, T1 on TPO 779.
